posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked:
Wondering if this design puts too much force on the bevel gears of the 90 gearbox. Had anyone broken one of these with their design? PXL_20250216_191021761 1920×2550 633 KB PXL_20250216_191328047.MP 1920×2550 835 KB

posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: from vibes alone, i’m feeling it’ll be fine, i’d fs test it out first

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Tested yesterday for several matches but wondering about longer term use and want to avoid failure as comp gets here.

posts.name: Ryan Swanson
posts.cooked: We (6045) direct drove our wrist in 2023 with a MAX 90. It experienced plenty of shock loads and we never had an issue with the gearbox. The only downside was the amount of backlash in the system which will be important for controlling your arm.

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: Thanks. Looks like you had some serious shock load, so good to know it survived.

posts.name: burde1jb
posts.cooked:
According to the product information failure occurs:

Gearbox ultimate strength - Failure at 180 NM +/- 5%

REV Robotics designs, builds and manufactures robotics parts and components used by students for learning about science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM). Our parts are commonly used within the FIRST Robotics Competition and the FIRST Tech...

Price: USD 85

Has my team broken these in the past due to use? Yup… tried to do a side climb in 2023 using one of these. There’s a really loud snapping noise to let you know that you have surpassed this limit.

posts.name: Ryan Burbo
posts.cooked: My team used a 90 degree to drive our arm last year, you could check out our cad in our OA thread but we had no problems with the gearbox. we have noticed that the regular couple does not support loads as well as the 90 degree we used them on our 2023 robot!

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Just out of morbid curiosity, do you remember what snapped?

posts.name: burde1jb
posts.cooked: The teeth on the bevel gear. The snapping sound was the teeth skipping under stress and the metal chipped rendering the gearbox unusable after.

posts.name: FredK
posts.cooked: What was the side climb in 2023?

posts.name: ben gates
posts.cooked:
I would say you’re fine. Don’t know the weight of your arm, but just eyeballing it based on your final drive reduction and the length of your arm, I can’t imagine the MAX90 breaking if assembled correctly.

I think REV also provides a max torque spec, so you can do some math to get an objective answer

edit: I need to start reading other replies first lol

Load ratings can be found here: MAX 90 Degree Gearbox - REV Robotics

You need to consider dynamic loads in addition to static loads, as they tend to be extremely large. For an arm like this, the dynamic loads in the torsion direction is just the effective moment of inertia times the acceleration. You might need to motion profile the arm to ensure this dynamic load plus the weight of the arm isn’t too much if the load ends up being too much, and might also want to consider jerk profiling.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked:
FredK:

What was the side climb in 2023?

It was going on the side of the charge station to leave room for teammates

We experienced a failure of a 90 degree gearbox, but only because the bolts holding the gearbox together came loose and allowed the gears to flex apart from each other, damaging the teeth.

I recommend taking out one screw at a time and loctite-ing them, then replacing.
